clinical_study.brief_title: Anti-CD19 CAR-T Therapy Bridging to HSCT for CD19+ B-Cell Malignancies
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase 1/2 Study Evaluating the Safety and Efficacy of Anti-CD19 Chimeric Antigen Receptor-Modified T Cell (CAR-T) Therapy Bridging to Hematological Stem Cell Transplantation (HSCT) for Relapsed/Refractory CD19+ B-Cell Malignancies

lead_sponsor.agency: Wuhan Sian Medical Technology Co., Ltd

clinical_study.source: Wuhan Sian Medical Technology Co., Ltd

brief_summary.textblock: Anti-CD19 chimeric antigen receptor (CAR)-modified T cell therapy has been confirmed effective for relapsed/refractory B-cell malignancies. However, its ability to keep patients in maintained remission is limited. In order to extend the remission time, investigators transfer patients who obtain remission through CAR-T therapy to hematological stem cell therapy (HSCT). The study aims to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of CAR-T therapy bridging to HSCT.

detailed_description.textblock: In order to keep patients in remissions as long as possible, patients who achieve remissions through CAR-T therapy will be transferred to HSCT if there are no contraindications.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Patients receive CAR-T therapy and HSCT.

primary_outcome.measure: Occurrence of study related adverse events
primary_outcome.description: defined as >= Grade 3（NCI CTCAE version 4.03） signs/symptoms, laboratory toxicities, and clinical events that are possibly, likely, or definitely related to study treatment

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of participants with an MRD negative complete remission after CAR-T therapy and HSCT
secondary_outcome.description: the efficacy of CAR-T therapy bridging to HSCT will be estimated based on the number of participants who have an MRD negative (flow cytometry) bone marrow aspirate following the treatment

arm_group.description: Once the patient achieves remission through Second generation CAR-T cells, he/she will be transferred to Hematological stem cell transplantation within 30 days.

intervention.description: Patients receive CD19 CAR-T cells transduced with a lentiviral vector on days 0, 1, and 2.
Patients receive hematological stem cell transplantation within 30 days once they achieve remission after CAR-T therapy.
